commentBody: All that comes to mind is: https://tinyurl.com/4rpss9ub

("I'll come too!" the duck said. "Just put it on my bill.")
Bruh

A lone rebus square.  How cute.  Pleasant puzzle otherwise.  

Seeing Kurt COBAIN put me in mind of the Mountain Goats song Love Love Love, which has the lyric:

And way out in Seattle young Kurt Cobain 
Snuck out to the greenhouse, put a bullet in his brain

This has got to be one of the most clever puzzles EYE have ever seen here.
Very enjoyable puzzle and a quick solve for me. I was glad the site connected the dots so I could see the RABBIT and the DUCK with minimal effort.
So clever.  loved it. Got a little bogged down in NW corner and that took me down the rabbit hole of Aristophanes works.
Oh, this was a good one! Thank you, Brad & Nicole. This was so much fun! Y‚Äôall have a great Wednesday!
Well done.
Loved the puzzle and loved the constructors' comments.
They must have given up on enforcing Rebus squares. I put in E alone, and the puzzle finished.

Ok, faster than my average Wednesday, but what can I do when this puzzle has me written all over it. First,My actual name, though I don‚Äôt play soccer. Second, I marched in marching band with the CSU Ft Collins Ram bands for 4 years. 2 Holiday Bowls included. Love seeing my CSU clued for once!!! 3rd, grew up with a rabbit and a duck. Whoo Hoo! Loved this
I believe both words of 7-down originated in England, and while used in all parts of Britain, are also used in other parts of the Commonwealth. Thus I think of them as English, not British.
Squee! Fun puzzle and the animation made me smile. Wonderful puzzle, whether you find it just ducky or a bit hare-raising.

Fantastic puzzle and certainly a nominee for POY in the M-W category.

Loved that eye...how it messed with you, got you looking for potential other rebuses, like one more eye, for instance. Kept you on your toes didnit? And the drawing at the end -- how I wished I was Barry Ancona who'd be drawing the line in by hand, whereas I was trying to trace it by eye (!) with absolutely no luck. So part of the pleasure of this puzzle is that it's meant to be done on the page and not the screen for best results.

And it was super tough in parts, the SE especially kept tripping me up, but it all came up roses. 

What a ton of fun!
The Love Yourself singer is the Biebs
Fun puzzle with hilarious constructor comments ‚Äî and let me give a shout-out to a great Mini today, which was unusually clever. Good job!
Fun puzzle but BUDICE is still available nationwide. Bud dry was discontinued in 2010.
Excellent puzzle, despite the pop culture cross of BIEB and CARELL.  Too much for this old stick in the mud.

Had an amazing time until the coy little rebus area came calling.

Then I descended into a hell of overly cutesy cluing and a twist that seems cruel for a Wednesday. All in the middle-right section, no less.

And I‚Äôll put that on my JDATE profile.
Sooo, we had a Wednesday on a Tuesday. And now a Thursday on a Wednesday?
Something to warm you up on this cold night. (What follows is good too.) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NcapxLsNlbc&list=RDNcapxLsNlbc&start_radio=1
Well THAT was cool. Made a rather rotten day a bit better at the end.
Cutest.  Puzzle.  Ever.
I took to this like a rabbit to water, bravo!

first there was the roadrunner with his sign (and falling anvil, was it?) from weeks ago and now this rabbit.
some puzzlers just have a porous border between left and right brain, apparently.
and more power to them, i say.

So far only positive comments, which is great, because I also liked it with some reservations (which some nay-sayers will be bringing up later, no doubt, with some fairness.)
First, the negatives‚Äîthis is a puzzle that would be more fun on paper than on the app, because you can only realistically see the image at the end. Second, if you don‚Äôt know Seth MEYERS you may not get the lone rebus from just ‚ÄîMASK, I think that should have been a little more explicit to be completely fair. Third the theme constraints made this a little tricky for a Wednesday, especially the middle east with the rebus (who knew the Middle East could be problematic?)

That said, this was a tour de force in terms of difficulty, with four revealers (two spanners) and a connect the dots to create some really clever grid art, not to mention the rebus. Don‚Äôt know which of these two conceived of this but it‚Äôs brilliant and to my mind all the negatives are forgiven and absolutely worth it.

A few clue comments;
Never heard of ‚Äúconservadox‚Äù and I‚Äôm Jewish, but it‚Äôs a great descriptor and I‚Äôm going to use it.
Don‚Äôt care for SRIRACHA but my son swears by it‚Äîofficially thanking him because I wouldn‚Äôt know it otherwise.
Don‚Äôt watch Seth MEYERS on TV but had the opportunity to watch his show live in New York recently, it was great fun and he is very talented.
Last I had OPTICAL ILLUSION and D-CK for ‚Äúwhat seem people think this image represents‚Äù. Not seeing the picture yet, U was not the first vowel to come to mind.

RABBIT v DUCK reminded me of the How I Met Your Mother episode‚Ä¶ https://youtu.be/6W7yhe1i-sQ?si=9GnBH_HTSR5H0Rcc Congratulations on your debut, Nicole. What a treat to construct with your dad. I hope to collaborate with at least one of my three kids someday on a puzzle. One can hope ü§ûüèº Happy Wednesday!

That lonely rebus had me mildly annoyed‚Äîit was the last square I filled‚Äîuntil I found my typo, got the gold star, and saw the drawing. (I knew it was coming, because I‚Äôd completed all the boxes.) Then I smiled. Well done, constructors!

Having no way to draw the pattern in the app as I solved was a huge flaw of this puzzle. Basically I was solving blind. Also, having that single rebus in an area of the grid where almost all entries were trivia-based was what ultimately made me lose my gold star. I had to look up almost everything there: I have no idea what JVS are, I've never heard of Conservadox or JDATE (I suppose it's a dating app for J... ews?), I know SAKS (sort of) but not as clued, ditto DORITOS. As I was on a googling spree, anyway, I checked the late night host too... And spoiled the rebus for myself.

I personally disliked it quite passionately, but I have a premonition this grid will win the Puzzle of the Year constest because it was "oh so cute" and "innovative".

Btw, if being so bad and rudimentary that it can be interpreted many ways makes an image an optical illusion, all my drawings deserve the label ü§£

Pretty fun puzzle. 

I didn't understand ACR as opposite of down. Could someone enlighten me?
This was very impressively done. Great job, Nicole and Brad.
Incredibly clever and just the right amount of challenging. Loved it.
Pleasantly surprised by the positivity in the comments. Was expecting this to be quite polarizing -- almost a Rorschach Test for those who love gimmicks and those who hate them :)
Wow!
Wow. Even leaving the incredible trick aside, this was such a gratifying solve. If there‚Äôs a puzzle of the year thing going on, I hope this is at least a finalist.
Did anyone else try to cram ‚Äúreligiousfigure‚Äù in there? I finally figured it out
Great puzzle, really liked the built-in illusion with the single rebus, nicely done!

This was a delight.

I was really struggling with MEYERS, trying to smash the name into four letters.  I felt a tremendous weight fall from my shoulders when I realized EYE made a ton of sense.

I think it's pretty rare to have only a single rebus, isn't it?

I like it a lot.  I suspect there is a tsunami brewing, though, which will make curb my enthusiasm about the whole affair.
Oops! Bud Ice was not discontinued in 2010. Bud Dry was.

This was cute and imaginative, and like others I appreciated the lone rebus. 

I‚Äôll take it a step further and say I‚Äôd enjoy constructors throwing in totally random rebus squares occasionally, apropos of nothing.

1. I loved this SO much!
2. How can I find a list of other crosswords that end up being a drawing/having a visual component to it? I know XWord exists but am wondering if there is another website (or longtime user here who keeps their favorites logged somewhere?)
3. I know this illusion is a classic but, as someone who has watched ‚ÄúSeverance‚Äù recently and for whom Milchick is a favorite character, it was a nice tie-in to ‚Äúreal‚Äù life!
a solo rebus. cute
Quaid army is going to love 30D, especially after Tuesday‚Äôs pod.

Was there something wrong with the comments section today?  It's 10 pm PST and only 75 comments?  And the oldest only 3 hours ago?  I started earlier today, and then realized just before  bed that I'd been side-tracked and never finished the puzzle.

But I did get Mike's pun.

And I liked the puzzle.  I had _MASK, which was a gimme.  I often put one on when I wake up at 6 am and want more sleep.  I never watch late night TV, so asked my husband about Seth.  He said MEYERS, but that didn't fit!  Then I was no longer in the dark!  EYEs wide open and seeing the rebus.  On a Wednesday!

That's OK.  It keeps me humble....

What clever construction, with good clues (they were just OBSCURE enough)! Also a really smooth solve with not a lost of crossword-ese. I smiled at my phone for a good 20 seconds when I saw the theme all come together.
Yes, I put a piece of paper over my phone and drew the image. Actually helped me solve the SW corner. ü¶Üüêá
I had a great time solving this one, but am honestly shocked to not see more negativity in the comments. The single rebus, yes, but also for my money this was closer to a Friday in difficulty. YMMV!

Great puzzle for a Wednesday! Took me way too long to solve it because of the single rebus, and the fact I did it on the app and didn't connect the dots visually. All in all, not very difficult, but a little tricky. Well done.

Is it a RABBIT or a DUCK?  It‚Äôs hard to say ...  
OPTICAL ILLUSION

It‚Äôs hard to say ... 
SORRY

SRIRACHA

LORES ??

I really have to learn to trust myself when my brain is telling me that something seems off. I am a fan of Seth Meyers, plus I remember that specific clue from a previous puzzle. (AND I often sleep with a sleep mask!) And yet, I fought the urge to use a rebus because it seemed to strange for there to only be one rebus answer in the whole puzzle Well, lesson Learned!

HA! I grinned ear to ear. My French pun: I was LAPIN‚Äô this up! (Can‚Äôt quite make canard make sense‚Ä¶)

I guess a marriage proposal would be inappropriate, but I do so love this puzzle. I love my tiny circle, but the constructors‚Äô friends and family must also feel like lucky people indeed.

Thanks, this really brightened an otherwise gloomy, under-the-weather evening for me!
Quaid Army

The answer for "Great service provider" is a little odd. I know them as a low-tier computer maker that occasionally has a reliable model, and their customer service has been spotty at best. The only other use of the word I've seen is for a genus of tree. Maybe that would be a better clue for this word.

I was on track to beat my record time for a Wednesday but that rebus threw me off. Meyers was the only one I had in mind but I kept digging my brain if there‚Äôs another Seth I‚Äôve missed. Good puzzle tho.

Superb puzzle, topped only by the constructors' notes. Bravo!

Thank you, Nicole and Brad!
Anyone thinking that Europe is the home of the UK must have slept through 2016.
Great puzzle! I was very impressed when I reached the end and saw the pattern. I thought it was very nicely constructed.
There can be no peace until they renounce their Rabbit God and accept our Duck God! https://condenaststore.com/featured/an-army-lines-up-for-battle-paul-noth.html

Loved the idea behind this puzzle! It was challenging for me and I spoiled it a bit around the rebus part... But it was fun and I can appreciate that it can bring a lot of joy to someone better at the specific trivia.

I also loved the constructor notes - short and to the point - denoting confidence and offering a glimpse into what must be a most fun father-daughter relationship! Very kind of them to put some of that into the world for us ‚ù§Ô∏è
lol can‚Äôt wait to see how many comments this one gets

I liked the puzzle's construction theme, but I think there were a bit too many US-specific clues that had me Googling: the two late-night hosts, Rapinoe, Superbowl, red carpet, the discontinued beer, conservadox... Seems consistent that most people saying they loved the puzzle are Americans, and the ones complaining about the trivia are foreigners.

What a delightful solve!! And love the punster father-daughter team's collaboration and notes. 
It was a nice challenge for me. Just enough to require some effort before the spaces started filling up.
Kudos to you both!

I don't know which I liked more, the puzzle or the constructor notes.  

Definitely on my short list for early week POY.

Oddly, I found myself broadly stuck until I noticed that circled letters in certain positions also had relationships alphabetically. That gave me a way* to reason through much of the connect-the-dots, and from the drawing I got the revealers and rebus and such.

Since there are several comments from experienced solvers noting higher difficulty in the clues, I would be interested if any others also had a different experience by doing the gimmick first. Perhaps that was intended to make up for the difficulty?

*(like Chekov's gun, none without purpose)
I wasn‚Äôt too crazy about this one.
I solve on paper but filled in the online grid 'cause EYE wanted to see the critters.  That and the constructors notes (congrats on the debut Nicole!!) - cuteNESS all around.  Thanks.
Loved loved loved this puzzle!

The single rebus in this puzzle threw the whole thing for me.
First, I stared at the void square for ten minutes trying to figure it out, then when I did make heads and tails of it (with a groan, admittedly) struggled how to fill in the rebus. I failed, but at that point had already thrown up my hands at the whole thing.
Ho-hum, lesson learned. Single miff about an otherwise fun Wednesday puzzle.

7 men, 5 brand names. 

If I wanted trivia I'd go to a pub quiz.
Great puzzle! It was fun to see the ambiguous image pop up in the online version!

The more I look at this, the more I see the puzzle with the blue lines, with the left eye of the duck and the right eye of the rabbit...

the idea for this puzzle is pure genius.  Pure, unadulterated genius.
Maybe I missed something said, but are we not impressed that the dots go alphabetically in order from A through N?

This one had everything I love: clever wordplay, secondary clues (the circled letters), an unexpected twist (the lone rebus), and end-of-puzzle animation.

It was also a relatively easy solve for me, as much of the trivia was right in my wheelhouse.  Seeing the pattern of the circled letters helped in filling out the rest. Although it‚Äôs funny that the rebus was an eye, because my eye could not foresee the image, no matter how many times I traced it with my finger! In the end, I felt like that rabducken was eyeing me with scorn.

Cute, and fun. What more could you ask for?

Constructor Notes of the Year.

CNOY.

And puzzle‚Ä¶

*Chef's kiss*

There was a lot going on in today‚Äôs puzzle! It was a bit more work than usual for Wednesday and I can sympathize with our foreign contributors regarding some of the trivia. 
The lone rebus was my last entry.
Wow! Wow! Fantastic puzzle, satisfying final image online, father-daughter constructors, and pun-filled constructor comments. That‚Äôs it, mic drop, I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever see better.

I have to say that the ‚Äúthis vs that‚Äù illusion here (which I assume is meant to echo the viral gold/blue dress and Yanni/Laurel episodes from a few years back) is working spectacularly for me: I can see a rabbit right away (in the app, post-solve), but for the life of me I cannot see that outline as a duck!

Also, I‚Äôll be the Nth commenter to applaud the constructors‚Äô notes ü§å

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Haven‚Äôt seen this illusion in a long time; didn‚Äôt remember it until it appeared and -- BOOM! -- elicited a huge smile.  
‚Ä¢	Pair of DOOKS ‚Äì LORES and STELMO.
‚Ä¢	The EYE was a happy surprise to figure out.
‚Ä¢	Fun fact: If you turn the grid 90¬∞ to the right, it‚Äôs also a rabbit.
‚Ä¢	I bet the most incredible moment for the constructors was when they discovered that theme answer DUCK‚Äôs C and D could be incorporated in the drawing.
‚Ä¢	The image is so blasted cute!  How cute?  It rivals this uber-cute grid: https: //www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/16/2022 (warning, this grid has the answers filled in).

I came to the grid neutral, Nicole and Brad, and left it with a warm heart at learning you are father and daughter, not to mention aflutter with joy from the explosion of cuteness you created.  What a lift ‚Äì thank you both!

29D. Arthur ASHE fits the clue better. Oh well...
Did a lot of Googling on this one and surprised to see the rebus. 
To me puzzle-wise, Tuesday's was a Wednesday and Wednesday was a Thursday.
how fun!!! i kept circling around *that* square until the very end.. i could have sworn i knew Seth's last name. finally it all made sense! wonderful wednesday today!!!!!

I went to bed after doing the puzzle last night thinking of that rabbit eye, and woke up this morning thinking of the Melvin Van Peebles song Eyes On The Rabbit which I vaguely remember hearing once back in the 70s.  I looked it up and, as Melvin tells it, he wrote it to be the sappiest song ever, and was surprised when his band members found it moving.
A rabbit for sure but maybe I haven‚Äôt kissed the right frog? This was such a fun but all too quick puzzle.

This was a really nicely done gimmick when it all came together, but alas, it exposed far too many gaps in my knowledge to get a gold star. I also couldn‚Äôt seem to find any real harmony between the clues and answers, so everything felt somewhat disconnected and almost like they were from two different puzzles, though this may have just been me having an off day.

JVS/JDATE/DORITOS was a tough one for non-Superbowl watching Englishman, and I did not expect that lone Rebus so assumed there must be some other Late Night Seth! 

Very nice execution and a fun concept though. 

Oh and for those who didn‚Äôt enjoy this and may be in need of a chuckle at my expense: I lost a great amount of time because I got thrown off after putting in FROGS‚Ä¶ I thought the R_BB_T I had at the bottom had to be RIBBIT, and therefore I was looking at an AMPHIBIANFIGURE - oops!
Unexpected rebuses are not exciting and fun. I enjoy getting the gold for a job well done and this wasn't it.
I really enjoyed it!

I'm apparently one of the few Americans who totally disliked this puzzle, for many of the reasons Andrjez cited. I did fill it all in without having to look up anything. I did connect all the circles. But the trivia was difficult for me. A beer that was discontinued in 2010? (I don't drink beer). The BIEB? ROADSTER? I haven't seen a car called that since I read the entire Nancy Drew mystery series when I was a child, and that was many decades ago. I, too, dislike non-linguistic gimmicks. I knew I'd be in a very small minority among my countrymen and women. But give me those words and smart clues. 

Also, having to connect the circles with a fine-point pen, without the end result gotten by those who solve online, didn't produce a very clear outline, so I had to look at xwordinfo's solution to see the clearer outline. Very tedious, especially solving in the middle of the night after getting both flu and covid vaccines late in the afternoon in the arm that does the writing!
This was so fun! And the anatomical fearure was my very last answer too.

I‚Äôm going to start a new thread since it would probably get lost otherwise, but this is in response to Francis‚Äô college football joke: how many college football players does it take to change a lightbulb?
5, but they get 4 credits a piece.
Letter connector "theme" with over a dozen bits of random/Naticky/unnecessary trivia topped off with an unindicted rebus. You certainly laid a 38D with this one...

A rebus on Wednesday!  
A bonus for us rebus-lovers!
And tricky, too, since the "Middle East" was the last to fall, and there was no reason to suspect a rebus until then.

That whole area would have been virtually unsolvable for me, until I realized I could fill in the two circled squares by running the alphabet and seeing which letters were missing.
Putting in J made JVS and J-DATE (Consevadox???) much easier, and the the K gave me SAKS, and ultimately made me recognize the need for the rebus [EYE], the last square to be entered.
And then came the music and the gold star.

Very clever!
Constructor Notes made me laugh! Very funny and clever.

I did this puz last night, thinking it was Tuesday‚Äôs‚Äîwhoops. I was going to post right then, to proclaim my love for this puzzle and to for once be in conversation with the first commenters (you know who you are!). But alas, it was late and my word-tap had run dry.  Next time. 

Anyway: what a treat! A solitary rebus must be a hard sell, but in context it made sense‚Äînot that it didn‚Äôt take me a minute to catch on. I appreciated that the down and ACR cluing over the rebus were so accessible. 

And such an adorable set of constructor notes! My own daughter just left for college; I miss her all the time and can only hope that one day we will enjoy such a fun and productive relationship as Brad and Nicole Wiegmann clearly do. Well done, you two!
I've been waiting patiently for a puzzle with just one rebus. My life is finally complete üòÉ Well, almost -- would like to see one with a rebus in every row or column.
Loved the constructor notes! Thank you, Wiegmanns!
Is anyone going to bring up the fact that Bud Ice was/is not discontinued?
Rebus on a Wednesday what is the world coming to shakin my head smh

Hmm...I read the column just in case I was missing something, and as usual, I was annoyed.  The attempt to gin up some confusion or difficulty (especially in the badly-titled "Tricky Clues" section) is condescending and irritating.  And it delayed my coffee.

ONward:  this was a fun puzzle to solve--nothing OBSCURE, but clued well enough to challenge at least momentarily.  My only slow-down was at 46A, where a sloppily printed D looked like a P in the third (last) square.  I note that I'd only seen the playwright's name spelt KYDD.  Delightful Constructors' Notes!

I vote RABBIT, albeit one who has been in some hard-fought battles (a la _Watership Down_) and ended up with slightly raggedy ears.  
I find myself hoping someone has a conniption fit over the (single) Rebus Square! (Exit, cackling.)
Let's just say I learned a lot today looking up all that trivia. But the theme did help the solve and EYE thought the rebus was quite clever and cute.

BUD ICE is still sold... BUD DRY was discontinued in 2010

Are these type of clues fact checked?

Quite a workout for me and must confess that I remained appropriately puzzled even when I had it all filled in. Had to come here to finally grasp what was going on. That's all on me. One somewhat appropriate puzzle find today. A Thursday from November 4, 2004 by Elizabeth C. Gorski. The reveal in that one was a five letter rebus across the center of the puzzle with the clue: "Huey, Dewey, Louie, Donald and Daisy" And that answer was five rebuses of 'DUCK." DUCKDUCKDUCKDUCKDUCK And... the very middle down crossing was a grid-spanning answer with the clue: "Do some planning before taking action." And that answer was: GETONESDUCKSINAROW And the other down crossings of that rebus were: WOOD(DUCK) ODD(DUCK) (DUCK)ING (DUCK)SOUP Thought that was all quite amazing. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/4/2004&g=39&d=A I'll put my other puzzle find in a reply. ....

This brilliant cartoon by Paul Noth was brought to my attention by @Gary from Amsterdam, but I'm afraid his link is so buried in the comments that not enough people will see it. It is not only the perfect accompaniment to today's puzzle, but also a hilarious evocation of the times we live in! https://norberthaupt.com/2015/11/22/the-rabbit-god-and-the-duck-god/

That was clever! Irritated at myself for not thinking of the rebus piece.

Anyone else only know "NESS" from "A state that's untouchable like Eliot ___"
Thank you Nicole and Brad Wiegmann. This was one of my favorite puzzles ever!

Some people think I look ugli,
while others say I‚Äôm just an old prune.

I don‚Äôt mind a rabbit of trivia,
but a couple more today and eye duck wit.
(But I duck wit it, and had some fun despite my wrinkles.)

This is the worst puzzle I've dealt with in my 5 or so months.

Saturday levels of endless crossing trivia and proper names.
One rhebus.
The image was hard to visualise in app, and the cluing around it felt just irritating. Ambiguous figure? Could be a great fill but a terrible pairing with the clue.

On top of the the grid was highly segmented.

I hated this, found it was an unenjoyable slog, and a waste of a rhebus puzzle.

And the clues were inaccurate in several places.

Just bad.
Really good clues and fills although the theme, one-off rhebus and graphic made for a weird puzzle. A little too much going on.
Nicole and Brad's constructor comments -- very punny!

Amazing! I can't imagine how difficult this must have been to construct: getting the shape right, getting the letters in order, putting the EYE in place. And there's still a good amount of fun fill: COBAIN, DORITOS, ROADSTER, BUD ICE, SRIRACHA.

Many thanks to the Wiegmanns!
Eye eye! One rebus you say? Clever.

Tricky, unexpected fun for a Wednesday!
Did anyone else have "Dominos" before DORITOS? That made the middle-right even more of a snarl.
See you tomorrow.

Loved everything about today‚Äôs puzzle esp in light of um er recent events ü§£ Congratulations to the father/daughter constructor team‚Ä¶wonderful. Have been solving nyt puzzles daily since the mid eighties‚Ä¶Miss the folding of the newspaper ‚Ä¶Miss the old ritual but love the gain of community. I wonder how many rebus puzzles I shrugged off in that span of time before phones and keyboards.

Wow what an interesting puzzle!!! When it is complete there is an A-HA moment‚Ä¶ And I thought very clever‚Ä¶ However, like so many others have said: This could easily be the worst puzzle ever! If I were new to crosswords on NYT I would never come back.

One Rebus? Are you serious? Again, it makes sense AFTER the puzzle is completed. This was the last entry I made before the music. And that is only because after completing it with the letter A in 37 I knew other answer was correct. I traced the shape and duck and rabbit made sense and that‚Äôs when I realized 37 was EYE! Again, very clever after the fact. But frustrating because A MASK also works except there is no Seth MARS (but honestly who knows, there seems to be a million evening talk show hosts)

But the I mage was hard to visualise in app and the clueing was AMBIGUOUS‚Ä¶ 

I can‚Äôt say I hated it. I actually enjoyed it, even though I was frustrated with trying to figure out how I had anything wrong. But I can understand where others would hate this puzzle.
Fun puzzle. Was dubious about the rebus. Love the constructors comments.

I don't know who I'm more upset with. the NYTXW platform, or myself. I am not on my A-game this morning, making stupid typos, and the like. When I got to the crossing of 30D and 37A, I was baffled. The only late night host I could think of was Seth Myers/Maiers/Meijers, but wouldn't fit. Does Bruno Mars have a brother who hosts talk show? Does Apple make a shielding device called an iMask? 

So I ran the Qwerty--well, only the vowels, natch. When I got to "E," the bell went off, the dabbit/ruck drew itself, and the rebus filled itself in. Doh!

So I solved the puzzle without solving the puzzle. Darn! (Which is too bad, as it was quite clever.)

***

An episode of *Letterkenny* features a dating app called Jswipe, for the more casually inclined.
Single rebus + silly drawing = meh, for me.

I loved this puzzle! It's cool to see a father - daughter team, and I think of my father often when doing crossword puzzles digitally on my phone. He was an avid puzzler my whole life, and brought the family into it, passing around the half-finished puzzle in the newspaper. He passed away 20 years ago - What would he think of my experience now, being able to quickly look up trivia and share comments with a worldwide group? He would be amazed, but would likely still do his puzzles with the newspaper:)

The thing is I couldn‚Äôt have known without either coming to this article or giving up‚Äîwhich raises an interesting tension in me personally and perhaps a meta-note on perspective. In a game predicated on rules, when the rule and form is broken (but not stated that it can/will be), is it therefore possible? And how would one know? For me the learn today was that sometimes you simply fail because of circumstances you didn‚Äôt about. Fair enough, take it on the chin and learn‚Äîand‚Äîit creates an unreliable narrator‚Äîwhich, to me, anyway, is less of a cleverness issue and more of a power imbalance. If what you seek to achieve is stumping, graduating or giving a moral lesson‚Äîthan mission accomplished. But if what you seek is to provide good thought with clever-yet-tough parameters that are clearly understood, well, this isn‚Äôt that. Constructors' Note of the year!

IMO, solvers who take crossword puzzles personally are tiresome. Sure, themes and grids might not be to your taste or liking, but the cleverness and thoughtfulness needed to create a puzzle like today‚Äôs is (are?) commendable, regardless of your personal feelings. Crosswords are meant to be brain exercises, asking us to think outside the box and expand our proverbial mental horizons. Authors/creators are not out to make *your* life in particular difficult. If you don‚Äôt like it, find another puzzle to try, or take the opportunity to learn from the grid for future solving (there are so many repeat clues/answers that I personally know nothing about, but because I‚Äôve been solving for years, I know who Brian ___ (3 letters) is, and what kind of cheese starts with an ‚ÄúE‚Äù (4 letters)).

@Jon Mark

If the answer was meant to refer to British as a language, it couldn't be written for an adjective (anything beginning with "like" is looking for an adjective).

Names of languages are nouns; the same word placed before "language" or any other noun (British food, British monarchy) is an adjective.

The usage of English or British as an answer to the clue is this adjectival form.  The word "hootenanny" is American; the word "billabong" is Australian; the word "begorrah" is Irish.  None of the above is naming a language, but rather what nationality uses that coinage.

The premier team at a school is the varsity team.  They are the A Team, the ones who get all the girls (or guys, depending) all the attention in the school newspaper and local, all the extra work makeup sessions to keep them eligible, all the tutors to do the actual work.

There was one major US football team associated with a university that tried to keep up.  You'd know if from a crossword.

Their star player was failing math, and an obstreperous instructor insisted that the star QB was failing and did not qualify for the rest of the season.

So they arranged to have a special single math question, which if he got right, would give him a pass.

All the alumni and donors were gathered in a huge auditorium.  The player was asked by the math teacher "What is one plus one?"

@Andrzej

There are three main branches of Judaism in the US (in other countries, they may have different names or be structurally different).

The most strict observers are Orthodox. They believe in a literal interpretation of the Hebrew Bible and follow every stricture meticulously.  They eat kosher, they don't mix linen and wool in their clothing, they rest on the Sabbath, including not lighting fires (and electricity), driving, etc. They observe every last holiday.  Because of this, they must live close enough to the synagogue to walk there on holy days and Sabbath. They pray three times a day, in Hebrew, genders separated. Men cover their heads at all times. Chasidism is an extreme form of Orthodoxy.

On the other end of the spectrum, Reform Jews are allowed to interpret the Bible as they see fit individually; therefore, most do not keep kosher, observe the Sabbath and holy days strictly or at all, and most Reform men only cover their heads when in synagogue, which is usually only on the Sabbath (or less), genders sit together. Prayer is a mix of Hebrew and English. 

Conservative Judaism is somewhat in the middle. Conservatives also usually only attend synagogue once a week, but the service is much longer; usually mixed gender, but not always. Many Conservatives eat kosher, but some only keep a kosher home, and not when they're out, and some not at all. 

When someone is called Conservadox, he or she is Conservative but leaning more toward Orthodox.

Hope this helps!

Now about high school sports.

You're correct, varsity is a corruption of university, but its usage has filtered down to the high school level as well.

The varsity football team is the one everyone goes to see on Friday night or Saturday afternoon.  They're the best and usually most experienced players.  

The JV, or junior varsity team, is the group of players with less experience and/or ability than the varsity team.  Only parents and close friends usually attend their games.  Some of them move up to the varsity eventually if they are good enough, but many don't.

Varsity teams may exist for a wide range of sports, while the JV may only exist for the most popular ones.  Therefore, you might find players of dubious ability on, say, the archery team, because there's only one of those.

High school sports heroes are a big deal, too, especially among their peer group, but not as much as college stars are.  The best college stars are likely to go on to the NFL or NBA and become instant millionaires. You can see why getting a degree might be thought of as a secondary goal.

US priorities...gotta love 'em!

@RayinVa

This is the David Connell method (David is an erstwhile commenter here):

When you get to a rebus square that is the last thing you have left to fill in, the puzzle will accept just the first letter.  If it bothers you that you will not get the chance to fill in the full word, delete one of the letters you already have in, then enter the rebus square, and then go back and re-enter the letter you just deleted.

The coding always allows just the first letter of the rebus to be accepted.  Some people appreciate this; others think it gives an unfair edge to those who are just guessing letters.  But that's how it is, and that's what you can do.

Personally, if I know what I intended to do, and I get my star, I don't care.
@RayinVa that‚Äôs how it always works, you only need to enter one letter of the rebus if you don‚Äôt want to use the rebus function
